Award.AwardTitle: IGERT: Integrative Graduate Education, Research, and Training in Population and Environment

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This IGERT program in population and environment has a focus on land use and land cover change. It features three longstanding interdisciplinary projects as "laboratories" for training and research: one based in Nang Rong, Thailand; a second in the Ecuadorean Amazon; and a third in Ngorongoro, Tanzania. Each project has as its overall goal a better understanding of human behavior and agency in the transformation of the Earth's surface. Deforestation, agricultural extensification, land fragmentation, intensification, degradation, secondary plant succession, and urbanization are unifying themes. The great strength and broader impacts of these projects collectively is their global reach and regional coverage. All involve collaboration with in-country scientists, who offer detailed local knowledge of field sites and data, facilitate fieldwork opportunities for trainees, and help to foster global perspectives on substantive and policy issues. The IGERT program will increase synergies within and across projects to the direct benefit of the trainees.

The intellectual merit of this program is that it builds on a firm base in a discipline (Ph.D.s are in a discipline or curriculum), adding coursework in complementary disciplines (population science for natural scientists; natural and spatial science for population scholars) and interdisciplinary training and research experiences. Scientists with a strong disciplinary base but with training in multiple perspectives will be ideally placed to bridge social, natural, and spatial science in research on population-environment interactions. The elements of the IGERT program are: a research apprenticeship on one of the population, land use, and environment projects; formal course work; participation in an ongoing interdisciplinary seminar; international field experience; and ethics training. In addition, an internship program will be created to involve undergraduates who are members of underrepresented groups in the projects and to encourage them to pursue interests in population and environment.

The IGERT training program will be housed at the Carolina Population Center (CPC) at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill (UNC-CH). IGERT trainees will be provided with fully equipped offices at the CPC, where IGERT project faculty (the principal and co-investigators of the projects) maintain research offices and where the projects are staffed and based. The IGERT program joins and extends interdisciplinary training programs at the CPC and the Curriculum in Ecology and UNC-CH. Further, as part of the IGERT program, CPC and the Nicholas School of the Environment and Earth Sciences at Duke University will jointly sponsor a series of distinguished lectures, colloquia, and workshops. These will focus attention on population, land use, and environment issues on both campuses and lay a foundation for future collaborations among students and faculty at both institutions.

IGERT is an NSF-wide program intended to meet the challenges of educating U.S. Ph.D. scientists and engineers with the interdisciplinary background, deep knowledge in a chosen discipline, and the technical, professional, and personal skills needed for the career demands of the future. The program is intended to catalyze a cultural change in graduate education by establishing innovative new models for graduate education and training in a fertile environment for collaborative research that transcends traditional disciplinary boundaries. In this sixth year of the program, awards are being made to institutions for programs that collectively span the areas of science and engineering supported by NSF.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The overarching goal of the IGERT program in population and environment was to train scientists who bridge the perspectives of social, natural, and spatial science to examine human populations as a driver of  land use  land change (LULC), and land use dynamics in relation to population outcomes. The Carolina Population Center (CPC) IGERT program in population and environment was, by design, interdisciplinary. Participating IGERT faculty represented the disciplines of anthropology, biostatistics, ecology, geography, public policy, and sociology.

 

The twenty-four trainees supported through the IGERT training program in population and environment since 2004-05 represent the disciplines of anthropology, city and regional planning, ecology, geography, health behavior and health education, maternal and child health, nutrition, and sociology. Of the twenty- four, thirteen have completed the PhD (87% completion rate), nine remain in doctoral programs and are supported by other sources, and two left the program without completing the PhD.  A strong disciplinary base with training and practical experience in multiple perspectives combined to form the ideal bridge for interdisciplinary team-based research.

 

Evidence of the program’s success can be found in the depth and breadth of IGERT faculty and trainee peer-reviewed publications, presentations, new courses inspired and developed as a result of the IGERT training program, the launch of new research programs resulting in human resource development and infrastructure building, an increase in the number of  intra- and inter-university research collaborations and  partnerships, and the development of an ongoing undergraduate internship program for underrepresented and disadvantaged students. During its project life-cycle, the IGERT training program in population and environment built a base of ongoing funded faculty research projects; the list of external grant awards expanded as the trainees successfully sought dissertation and fieldwork support.

 

Benefits of the IGERT program extend beyond the specific students involved. As a result of this program, five new graduate seminars are now offered, three graduate workshops, and two interdisciplinary undergraduate courses focused on population-environment interactions --- to the benefit of all students at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill (UNC). In addition, the UNC Graduate School, Office of Biomedical Graduate Education, and other departments such as Geography are consulting the tracking systems we developed to follow graduates from our program as examples on which to base their own systems.

 

As a result of the IGERT training program in population and environment, an international partnership has developed between UNC and the leading academic institution in Ecuador, key organizations in the Galapagos Islands, international conservation groups, and government organizations in Ecuador. The now established collaborative partnership offers an unparalleled opportunity for interdisciplinary study of complex and integrated social, terrestrial, and marine interactions. Stakeholders are based at CPC with the new UNC Center for Galapagos Studies, the Universidad San Francisco de Quito (USFQ), the new Galapagos Science Center (a joint UNC & USFQ research center on San Cristobal), the Galapagos National Park, the Charles Darwin Foundation & Research Station, and non-governmental organizations (NGO) with a global conservation mandate and a significant presence in the Galapagos – specifically, the World Wildlife Fund and Conservation International. This IGERT training program was also instrumental in establishing a new partnership between CPC and the Regional Institute of Population Studies at the University of Ghana.
